recordings.loc: Cedarville Township (near  Stephenson), Menominee County, Michigan
recordings.rmk: Unmodified recording. Adult bird in tree overlooking marsh, where juvenile was hidden at first. As I approached on the path, adult gave Khow call and then alarm call, at which the juvenile flew clumsily out of the cattails and landed a short distance away.  Adult plumage appeared to be in good condition, and juvenile was almost as large as the adult also with similar plumage and a noticeable crest. I don't know whether it was the adult or the juvenile or both who made the Kek series calls. The adult flew as I walked under the branch where it had been perched. I saw two Green Herons flying at different times in the vicinity, possibly the same one twice.

recordings.file-name: XC268817-Green Heron in mangroves in canal, disturbed by me -FL, Pine Island Conservation Area, August 17, 2015, 0709 AM.mp3
recordings.rmk: in canal on mangrove, disturbed by me and flew away

This 1+ minute long recording documents 7 vocalizations of a Green Heron. The vocalist was not seen uttering these noises. However, there were Green Herons in the area and even in the tree that this vocalist was in. The sound source was within 15 meters of the microphone. This file begins with all 7 vocs back to back for comparative purposes and to display well on the spectrogram. This prelude is followed by a second of silence. What follows that is the unedited and unmodified recording of the natural spacing of this bird’s utterances.

The first 4 and then 7th calls have a introductory element which is reminiscent of the typical “skow” vocalization but softer and not as loud. That introductory element grades into a low-pitched growl. The 5th and 6th calls begin at 0:05.3 lack the introductory element and seem to be solely the growl. Could be the male song as described in the account "During breeding season, advertising calls or song by male are show-ch or ow-ch (Townsend 1928). Low-pitched skow call given from top of tree or other perch with bill up at 45° angle."

Additional details regarding context may be found at: <http://ebird.org/ebird/view/checklist?subID=S23971407>

This recording was made with an iPhone 5s with the on-board microphone and Røde Rec application.

recordings.file-name: XC256633-2015_07_12 0809 Green Heron, Cataratas de Pulhapanzak, San Buenaventura, Cortes, HON.mp3

recordings.rmk:
This 20-second long recording documents 2 flight displays of an adult Green Heron. This heron did an aerial display within the canopy of an Red Alder. It only made a mechanical noise with its wings. This heron had just flown into the tree from the river bed. It landed and perched for a few seconds. It then flew with the body held at a 45˚ angle and a hunched back. The wings were not lifted much above horizontal but were deeply flapped under the body. The wings were quite flared. This noise was created in the downflap. This bird flapped 10 times. This bird landed perhaps 5 meters above where it took off and disappeared from view and was not seen again. At 0:19 it made a second display also with 10 flaps. The sound source was within 15 meters of the microphone. This cut is an unedited and unmodified recording of the natural spacing of this bird’s display.

This is what the Birds of North America account has to say: "Flap Flight Display is highest intensity of flight displays, where male lurches through air with exaggerated flapping producing whom-whoom-whoom sound, neck crooked, legs dangling, skow ing, crest, neck, and scapular feathers erect, sometimes giving roo-roo calls before landing."

Davis, Jr., W. E. and J. A. Kushlan. 1994. Green Heron (Butorides virescens), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/129

Additional details regarding context may be found at: <http://ebird.org/ebird/view/checklist?subID=S23971407>

This recording was made with an iPhone 5s with on-board microphone and Røde Rec application.
ID certainty 100%. (Archiv. tape 72 side B track 5 seq. A)
